docs.snippet: Fox's teenage soap opera ''The OC,'' once a promising ratings draw for the younger viewers prized by advertisers, mustered only a modest audience on Thursday in its series finale at 9 p.m. According to Nielsen's estimates, 6.7 million viewers tune...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fox's teenage soap opera ''The OC,'' once a promising ratings draw for the younger viewers prized by advertisers, mustered only a modest audience on Thursday in its series finale at 9 p.m. According to Nielsen's estimates, 6.7 million viewers tuned in for the episode, a 76 percent improvement over its average this season, but still far behind its series high of 12.7 million viewers in January 2004 during its first full season. Although Fox strategically broadcast the finale after the ''American Idol'' results show, which dominated the 8 o'clock hour with 24.2 million viewers, ''The O.'' faced tremendous competition at 9 from CBS's ''CSI'' (21.6 million) and ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy,'' which earned a season-high 27.3 million viewers in the hour. At 10, opposite ABC's ''Oprah Winfrey Oscar Special'' (15.8 million), and CBS's ''Shark'' (14.3 million), NBC's ''ER'' drew 9.9 million total viewers and posted its lowest ratings among adults 18 to 49 in its 12-and-a-half-year history. NBC finished a distant fourth for the night. Fox ranked second in the 18-to-49 demographic but third in total viewers behind CBS. ABC was first over all. BENJAMIN TOFF
docs.abstract: ABC wins ratings for Thursday night; finale of teen drama The OC on Fox draws lower than expected ratings (S)

headline.main: Arts, Briefly; Modest Finale for 'The OC'

byline.original: By BENJAMIN TOFF; Compiled by Seth Gilmore

docs.snippet: Finally, after months of anticipation, with a cast of thousands: The Bagger's Oscar Picks....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger knew this day would come. All of his juking and jiving could not avoid the day of reckoning, when idle speculation would be replaced by landing hard on some softly held convictions. But confession, or at least disclosure, is good for the soul.
docs.abstract: Finally, after months of anticipation, with a cast of thousands: The Bagger's Oscar Picks.

docs.snippet: The Bagger looks at art and at the people who look at art in L.A....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger attended the opening of "Superstition," a show of works by Damien Hirst at the Gagosian Gallery in Beverly Hills. The Bagger had no idea why he was there, other than the fact that Baguette told him to go -- that it was the unofficial start of the Oscar parties -- and he does everything she tells him to. There was a block long line to get in, which the Bagger busted just by keeping moving and carrying an air of insouciance.
docs.abstract: The Bagger looks at art and at the people who look at art in L.A.

headline.main: The Flap of a Butterfly's Wings

docs.snippet: The great and near-great films that got no love from Oscar....
docs.lead_paragraph: The "best" best picture of all time? "The Godfather." The worst? Why of course, it's "The Greatest Show on Earth." So says Rotten Tomatoes, which has a keen web portfolio that rates all the best pictures in Academy history from a critical perspective.
docs.abstract: The great and near-great films that got no love from Oscar.

docs.snippet: One Oscar picker who decided to take the day off....
docs.lead_paragraph: This year, Kim Masters is picking to not make her picks, a bold move that comports nicely with the realities of the race.Then again, maybe its just a smarty-pants ways of ducking the confused issue. (BTW, Masters has a really smart piece on Oscar presenter Tom Cruise as well.)
docs.abstract: One Oscar picker who decided to take the day off.
